title: Mediterranean pass
text:
The Mediterranean pass (or Mediterranean passport, the name used in the United States) was a document which identified a ship as being protected under a treaty with states of the <a href="Barbary%20Coast">Barbary Coast</a>. Such a treaty exacted tribute in exchange for protection from <a href="Barbary%20pirate">Barbary pirate</a>s capturing that country's ships and crews. These passes identified ships which had safe passage.
The top of the British document was <a href="indenture">cut off in an erratic scalloped pattern</a> used to confirm its authenticity. The matching top of the document was sent to officials along the Barbary Coast, so <a href="cruiser">cruiser</a>s from those ports would have samples for comparison with the edge of the documents. A similar design was adopted by the United States, although U.S. Consul General in Algiers Richard O'Brien pointed out the document should be on thicker paper (or parchment) and kept in a tin container so as to ensure a better match between tops and bottoms (he also suggested that ships fly the <a href="American%20flag">American flag</a> rather than the flags of individual states).
Countries known to have issued such documents include:
The United States issued Mediterranean passports starting with a September 5, 1795, treaty with the Dey of Algiers,
and continuing through the mid-19th century.
Background.
For about 300 years, the <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> lanes were largely controlled by the <a href="north%20Africa">north Africa</a>n Muslim states of the <a href="Barbary%20Coast">Barbary Coast</a> (Tripoli, Algiers, <a href="Morocco">Morocco</a>, and <a href="Tunis">Tunis</a>) through <a href="piracy">piracy</a>. <a href="Hostage">Hostage</a>s were either <a href="ransom">ransom</a>ed or sold into <a href="slavery">slavery</a>. Over time, most countries found it expedient to simply pay a yearly <a href="tribute">tribute</a> (<a href="bribe">bribe</a>) to the Barbary <a href="sultan">sultan</a>s in exchange for safe passage through the Mediterranean.
Following the <a href="American%20Revolution">American Revolution</a>, the United States was no longer under the protection of the British tribute treaties, resulting in the crippling of American commerce in the Mediterranean. Having no significant <a href="United%20States%20Navy">navy</a>, the U.S. decided to form tribute treaties with the Barbary states, such as the 1796 <a href="Treaty%20of%20Tripoli">Treaty of Tripoli</a>. This treaty required ship's passports within 18 months.
